name: places/ChIJSzVEzXlZwokR_9l4rrI7U0s
adrFormatAddress: 326 2nd Ave, New York, NY 10003, USA

originalText.text:
Anthony Marano at East Coast Prosthetics has given me the best prosthetic experience I have had in my 30-plus years as an amputee. I have now worked with four prostheticians over the years, and in each of the three previous cases, there came a time when communications frazzled or a fit issue was not able to be addressed. After going through a rough patch with my last prosthetic provider, I resolved to find a better solution.

Anthony has an affiliation at the Rusk Institute, and I was connected to him through a physician at NYU Langone. I had been on crutches for a while and we talked as I concluded treatment with the physicians. I came to understand that Anthony is a very experienced prosthetist, but equally important to me were his listening skills. My time off limb had led to doubt and self-questioning, but with Anthony I got to speak my piece and felt I was a partner in creating the new, ideal limb, not just a patient ready to take what was offered. With his experience, Anthony was able offer solutions that had not surfaced with previous providers. And these were not always the latest gizmos, but rather a selection of old and new technologies that were customized to my particular, and often particularly frustrating, circumstances.

Because of my previous fit issues we moved slowly and carefully, and managed to avoid setbacks. I have been able to reach out to him directly as needed, and when a fit issue comes up, I am able to see him quickly (usually the next day). He's good about text communications too--sometimes you don't need a visit, but just reassurance or advice on a particular matter.

In terms of East Coast Prosthetics, I will say that the offices are not particularly great. I had initially checked their location on Broadway in Washington Heights, and I was completely underwhelmed by the shabby office and the disinterested response to my questions. When I started working with Anthony and first visited the 2nd Ave/19th St location, I was shocked at the condition of the facilities--the staff never rolls up the security gates, so the place looks and feels a bit like a prison. The exam rooms are small, there is no adequate place to do test walks, and the walls are marked or damaged and badly in need of painting. It would be great if they put a little more TLC into the facilities.

originalText.text: These people are a waste of time. They took over a month to come up with scheme to charge me after it had been established that my orthotic was covered by my insurance. I doubt it would have helped anyway.

text.text: These people are a waste of time. They took over a month to come up with scheme to charge me after it had been established that my orthotic was covered by my insurance. I doubt it would have helped anyway.

originalText.text: I had a brace for a broken humerus that was so uncomfortable, and Roman at this location refitted it twice for me.  I will be forever grateful for his expertise and kindness!
